attributes.title: Social media survey
attributes.description: The past decade has seen a rapid increase in the use of social media, with a recent report indicating that 66% of the UK’s population are active social media users (Underwood, 2020). Although the term "social media addiction" is widely used in mass media and public discussion to describe excessive usage, whether this behaviour should be pathologised as a behavioural addiction is still hotly contested in the scientific literature, and currently no formal diagnosis of social media addiction exists (Griffiths, Kuss, & Demetrovics, 2014). In order to identify when/if excessive social media use may become problematic in the sense of predominant theoretical models of addiction, which rely heavily on the concept of reward (Berridge & Robinson, 2016; Robinson & Berridge, 1993), research must first clarify the rewarding aspects of social media that might perpetuate excessive use. Previous research indicates an important role for a range of reward-related motives (Kircaburun, Alhabash, Tosuntaş, & Griffiths, 2018; Przybylski, Murayama, DeHaan, & Gladwell, 2013; Ryan, Chester, Reece, & Xenos, 2014; Zolkepli, Kamarulzaman, & Kitchen, 2018) in social media use but the relative contribution of these motives to excessive usage and problematic behaviour remains unclear. The present study will therefore aim to systematically measure how much reward-based motives contribute to social media usage and how they predict problematic social media use. The study will use different subjective measures related to social media, including assessment of different types of reward-based motives underlying social media use, problematic social media usage behaviours based on the Social media disorder scale (Van Den Eijnden, Lemmens, & Valkenburg, 2016) derived from DSM criteria for addiction, and general sensitivity to reward using a questionnaire. The study will also employ experimental paradigms derived from the substance addiction and food reward literature to assess reward related to social media implicitly. These measures will focus on the motivational component of reward (wanting), as changes of the neural system underlying wanting (mesolimbic dopaminergic system) are implicated in excessive drug use (Lambert, McLeod, & Schenk, 2005; Leyton, et al., 2002), alcohol consumption (Ostafin, Marlatt, & Troop-Gordon, 2010) and obesity (Mela, 2006; Volkow, Wang, & Baler, 2011). Measures will include (a) visual cue reactivity to social media logos (and control logos) as a proxy for cue-elicited wanting (Berridge & Robinson, 2016), (b) a visual approach-avoidance task to examine approach motivation associated with wanting (Kakoschke, Albertella, Lee, & Wiers, 2019), (c) and pay-for-likes as an analogue to pay-for-food wanting measures (Rogers & Hardman, 2015). In addition, we will measure self-reported urges (wanting) to check social media and pleasure (liking) associated with social media usage. The incentive sensitization theory of addiction (Berridge & Robinson, 2016; Robinson & Berridge, 1993) predicts that increased wanting should occur independent of liking. Both components of the study (self-reports and experimental measures) will be administered in an online survey programmed using PsyToolkit (Stoet, 2010; Stoet, 2017).

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1a: The presence of self-reported reward-based motives (across types of reward-based motives) is positively associated with frequency of checking social media and problematic usage. 

Hypothesis 1b: Based on pilot data, we predict “impression management” and “entertainment” to be the strongest predictors of frequency of checking and problematic usage.

Hypothesis 2: Mirroring findings in substance addiction, self-reported wanting but not pleasure/liking of social media use is positively related to frequency of checking and problematic usage.

Hypothesis 3: The difference between visual cue reactivity to social media versus control logos is larger in individuals with higher usage and larger in individuals with more problematic usage.

Hypothesis 4: The difference between the approach RTs to social media logos and approach RTs to control logos is negatively associated with frequency of checking and problematic usage (i.e., faster social media approach tendencies will predict more excessive/problematic usage). 

Exploratory analysis:
The effects of secondary variables (i.e., expected likes, pay-for-likes, general reward sensitivity, self-awareness of problematic use, and changes in self-reported usage behaviour since the outbreak of COVID-19) will also be investigated in exploratory analyses. 

To evaluate the relative contribution of all self-report and implicit wanting measures, these will be also evaluated in combined analysis. Moreover, relationships between regressor variables will be assessed.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Recruitment: Participants will be recruited using standard internal channels of advertising research studies at Durham University (e.g., the “SONA” participant credit system for Psychology students, the University newsletter, social media pages), as well as external channels of advertising (e.g., www.prolific.co). 

Eligibility criteria: Participants between the ages of 18 and 30 years old, who are able to access visual information on their computer screen without any special equipment, such as a speech interface or the “Accessibility Mode” of the operating system, will be eligible to take part. The study will also require that participants access the survey on a device with a real keyboard and using a browser other than Safari (because of incompatibility with the experiments coded on PsyToolkit). 

Procedure: Participants who meet the eligibility criteria will be invited to take part in the study and will access the survey programmed using PsyToolkit (Stoet, 2010; Stoet, 2017) via a web link. Participants who confirm the consent agreement will first be asked to report demographic information (e.g., age and gender). They will then be asked questions related to their social media use, including the types of social media platforms they use, their daily time spent on social media and frequency of checking. Further questions related to social media usage will explore how daily time spent using and frequency of checking might have changed since the outbreak of the COVID-19 virus. Secondary variables will then be measured including the number of expected ‘likes’ on a social media post and the willingness to ‘pay-for-likes’, for which participants are asked to choose between an incremental amount of money (i.e., £1, £2, £5, £10, £25, £50, £100) or doubling the number of ‘likes’ on their next social media post. Participants will then complete the ‘Social Media Disorder Scale’ (a 9-item scale adapted from the DSM criteria for Internet Gaming Disorder; Van Den Eijnden, Lemmens, & Valkenburg, 2016), as a measure of problematic social media use. This will be followed by questions assessing the degree to which their social media use represents a “liking” vs. “wanting” behaviour. Participants will then be asked to report the extent to which they agree with 20 statements that assess 10 pre-identified categories of rewards and motivations related to social media use (two statements per each domain). The final part of the questionnaire will assess general sensitivity to reward using 10 items taken from the SPSRQ-20 (Aluja & Blanch, 2011), a short form of the Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (Torrubia, Avila, Moltó, & Caseras, 2001). All questions in the questionnaire will be optional and participants can choose to omit any they do not wish to answer. After completing the questionnaire component of the study participants will complete an Online Visual Approach/Avoidance by the Self Task (online-VAAST) with social media and matched control stimuli, as an implicit measure of automatic approach tendencies to social media cues. Finally, participants will be asked to self-report whether they believe they use social media too much and whether they believe they are addicted, before finishing the survey. In total the survey is expected to take approximately 30 minutes to complete.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 400 participants.

q12.value: Relationship maintenance is frequently cited as a primary use of social media (Ryan, Chester, Reece, & Xenos, 2014; Sheldon, 2009). Based on our pilot study we found only a weak non-significant relationship between relationship maintenance and excessive use (r = .164). We used this correlation to calculate the sample size we would need to detect an effect with a power of 90% at p < .05 using G*Power. The total sample size required to detect an effect was calculated to be 386. Thus, a target sample of 400 participants is proposed.

question.value:
All statistical analyses will be run in parallel with the inclusion of variables to either predict excessive social media use (frequency of checking/daily hours spent using) or problematic social media use (average scores on the Social Media Disorder Scale). Both ‘daily hours spent using’ and ‘Social Media Disorder Scale’ questions will produce interval data. However, the ‘frequency of checking’ question uses a 7-item Likert-scale response, producing ordinal data which is typically analysed using nonparametric tests. Nevertheless, it has been convincingly argued that Likert-scale variables with 5 or more categories can be treated as continuous and analysed using parametric methods without concern for producing spurious statistical results, even when statistical assumptions (e.g., such as a normal distribution of data) are violated (Norman, 2010; Sullivan & Artino Jr., 2013). We will therefore analyse all our data using linear regression analyses to preserve the information in the ordering of the data. 

Hypothesis 1: Average scores across each of the 10 reward-based motives will be entered into a stepwise regression analysis to determine overall predictive utility of reward-based motives and to establish the variables that are the strongest predictors of excessive and problematic social media use. 

Hypothesis 2: Average scores on the ‘liking’ and ‘wanting’ questions will be entered into a hierarchical regression analysis to assess the unique proportion of variance of ‘wanting’ on excessive and problematic social media use. 

Hypothesis 3: Cue reactivity score to social media logos (i.e., cue reactivity rating for social media – control logos) will be analysed using a univariate linear regression. 

Hypothesis 4: First both automatic approach and avoidance tendencies for social media vs. control logos will be analysed using paired samples t-tests in order to investigate whether the sample as a whole had robust automatic approach or avoidance tendencies for social media. Next, the predictive value of the two variables will be assessed using a hierarchical linear regression. If the assumption of non-multicollinearity is not met, separate regression models will be used for approach vs avoidance RTs.

q19.value: A standard p-level of 0.05 will be used for statistical inference and effect sizes will be computed using partial eta squared and Cohen’s d. Planned analyses will be adjusted for multiple comparisons where appropriate (using the Holm-Bonferroni method).

q20.value: In cases where participants do not reach the last screen of the survey and confirm the submission of their anonymised data, any recorded data will be deleted and not included in any analysis. Data will also be excluded from participants who do not answer a sufficient number of questions to warrant inclusion (> 1/3 of questions). In the online-VAAST reaction time data below 200 ms and above 3000 ms will be excluded. Data will also be excluded from participants whose accuracy rate is suboptimal (i.e., <60% and therefore comparable to chance).

q22.value:
Exploratory analysis will investigate the relationship between secondary variables (i.e., expected likes, pay-for-likes, general sensitivity to reward and self-reported problematic use) and excessive/problematic social media use. Exploratory analysis will also be conducted to investigate potential changes in self-reported social media usage after the outbreak of COVID-19. 

Significant predictor variables identified in the main analyses will also be entered into a combined regression analysis to determine the strongest predictor variables for excessive/problematic use.

q23.value:
References
Aluja, A., & Blanch, A. (2011). Neuropsychological behavioral inhibition system (BIS) and behavioral approach system (BAS) assessment: A shortened sensitivity to punishment and sensitivity to reward questionnaire version (SPSRQ–20). Journal of Personality Assessment, 93, 628-636.

Aubé, B., Rougier, M., Muller, D., Ric, F., & Yzerbyt, V. (2019). The online-VAAST: A short and online tool to measure spontaneous approach and avoidance tendencies. Acta psychologica, 201, 102942.

Berridge, K. C., & Robinson, T. E. (2016). Liking, wanting, and the incentive-sensitization theory of addiction. American Psychologist, 71, 670.

Kakoschke, N., Albertella, L., Lee, R. S., & Wiers, R. W. (2019). Assessment of automatically activated approach–avoidance biases across appetitive substances. Current Addiction Reports, 6, 200-209.

Kircaburun, K., Alhabash, S., Tosuntaş, Ş. B., & Griffiths, M. D. (2018). Uses and gratifications of problematic social media use among university students: A simultaneous examination of the big five of personality traits, social media platforms, and social media use motives. International Journal of Mental Health and Addiction, 1-23.

Lambert, N. M., McLeod, M., & Schenk, S. (2005). Subjective responses to initial experience with cocaine: An exploration of the incentive-sensitization theory of drug abuse. Addiction, 101, 713-725.

Leyton, M., Boileau, I., Benkelfat, C., Diksic, M., Baker, G., & Dagher, A. (2002). Amphetamine-induced increases in extracellular dopamine, drug wanting, and novelty seeking: A PET/[11C] raclopride study in healthy men. Neuropsychopharmacology, 27, 1027-1035.

Mela, D. J. (2006). Eating for pleasure or just wanting to eat? Reconsidering sensory hedonic responses as a driver of obesity. Appetite, 47, 10-17.

Norman, G. (2010). Likert scales, levels of measurement and the “laws” of statistics. Advances in Health Sciences Education, 15, 625-632.

Ostafin, B. D., Marlatt, G. A., & Troop-Gordon, W. (2010). Testing the incentive-sensitization theory with at-risk drinkers: Wanting, liking, and alcohol consumption. Psychology of Addictive Behaviors, 24, 157.

Przybylski, A. K., Murayama, K., DeHaan, C. R., & Gladwell, V. (2013). Motivational, emotional, and behavioral correlates of fear of missing out. Computers in Human Behavior, 29, 1841-1848.

Robinson, T. E., & Berridge, K. C. (1993). The neural basis of drug craving: An incentive-sensitization theory of addiction. Brain Research Reviews, 18, 247-291.

Rogers, P. J., & Hardman, C. A. (2015). Food reward. What it is and how to measure it. Appetite, 90, 1-15.

Rougier, M., Muller, D., Ric, F., Alexopoulos, T., Batailler, C., Smeding, A., & Aubé, B. (2018). A new look at sensorimotor aspects in approach/avoidance tendencies: The role of visual whole-body movement information. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 76, 42-53.

Ryan, T., Chester, A., Reece, J., & Xenos, S. (2014). The uses and abuses of Facebook: A review of Facebook addiction. Journal of Behavioral Addictions, 3, 133-148.

Sheldon, P. (2009). Maintain or develop new relationships? Gender differences in Facebook use. Rocky Mountain Communication Review, 6, 51-56.

Stoet, G. (2010). PsyToolkit - A software package for programming psychological experiments using Linux. Behavior Research Methods, 42, 1096-1104.

Stoet, G. (2017). PsyToolkit: A novel web-based method for running online questionnaires and reaction-time experiments. Teaching of Psychology, 44, 24-31.

Sullivan, G., & Artino Jr., A. R. (2013). Analyzing and interpreting data from Likert-type scales. Journal of Graduate Medical Education, 5, 541-542.

Torrubia, R., Avila, C., Moltó, J., & Caseras, X. (2001). The Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (SPSRQ) as a measure of Gray's anxiety and impulsivity dimensions. Personality and Individual Differences, 31, 837-862.

Underwood, L. (2020, February 2020). Digital 2020: The UK - what you need to know. Retrieved from We Are Social: https://wearesocial.com/uk/blog/2020/02/digital-2020-the-uk-what-you-need-to-know

Van Den Eijnden, R. J., Lemmens, J. S., & Valkenburg, P. M. (2016). The social media disorder scale. Computers in Human Behavior, 61, 478-487.

Volkow, N. D., Wang, G. J., & Baler, R. D. (2011). Reward, dopamine and the control of food intake: Implications for obesity. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 15, 37-46.

Zolkepli, I. A., Kamarulzaman, Y., & Kitchen, P. J. (2018). Uncovering psychological gratifications affecting social media utilization: A multiblock hierarchical analysis. Journal of Marketing Theory and Practice, 26, 412-430.

registration_responses.q6.question: Independent samples design
registration_responses.q10.question:
Recruitment: Participants will be recruited using standard internal channels of advertising research studies at Durham University (e.g., the “SONA” participant credit system for Psychology students, the University newsletter, social media pages), as well as external channels of advertising (e.g., www.prolific.co). 

Eligibility criteria: Participants between the ages of 18 and 30 years old, who are able to access visual information on their computer screen without any special equipment, such as a speech interface or the “Accessibility Mode” of the operating system, will be eligible to take part. The study will also require that participants access the survey on a device with a real keyboard and using a browser other than Safari (because of incompatibility with the experiments coded on PsyToolkit). 

Procedure: Participants who meet the eligibility criteria will be invited to take part in the study and will access the survey programmed using PsyToolkit (Stoet, 2010; Stoet, 2017) via a web link. Participants who confirm the consent agreement will first be asked to report demographic information (e.g., age and gender). They will then be asked questions related to their social media use, including the types of social media platforms they use, their daily time spent on social media and frequency of checking. Further questions related to social media usage will explore how daily time spent using and frequency of checking might have changed since the outbreak of the COVID-19 virus. Participants will then complete the ‘Social Media Disorder Scale’ (a 9-item scale adapted from the DSM criteria for Internet Gaming Disorder; Van Den Eijnden, Lemmens, & Valkenburg, 2016), as a measure of problematic social media use. This will be followed by questions assessing the degree to which their social media use represents a “liking” vs. “wanting” behaviour. Participants will then be asked to report the extent to which they agree with 20 statements that assess 10 pre-identified categories of rewards and motivations related to social media use (two statements per each domain). The final part of the questionnaire will assess general sensitivity to reward using 10 items taken from the SPSRQ-20 (Aluja & Blanch, 2011), a short form of the Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire (Torrubia, Avila, Moltó, & Caseras, 2001). registration_responses.q17.question:
All statistical analyses will be run in parallel with the inclusion of variables to either predict excessive social media use (frequency of checking/daily hours spent using) or problematic social media use (average scores on the Social Media Disorder Scale). Both ‘daily hours spent using’ and ‘Social Media Disorder Scale’ questions will produce interval data. However, the ‘frequency of checking’ question uses a 7-item Likert-scale response, producing ordinal data which is typically analysed using nonparametric tests. Nevertheless, it has been convincingly argued that Likert-scale variables with 5 or more categories can be treated as continuous and analysed using parametric methods without concern for producing spurious statistical results, even when statistical assumptions (e.g., such as a normal distribution of data) are violated (Norman, 2010; Sullivan & Artino Jr., 2013). We will therefore analyse all our data using linear regression analyses to preserve the information in the ordering of the data. 

Hypothesis 1: Average scores across each of the 10 reward-based motives will be entered into a stepwise regression analysis to determine overall predictive utility of reward-based motives and to establish the variables that are the strongest predictors of excessive and problematic social media use. 

Hypothesis 2: Average scores on the ‘liking’ and ‘wanting’ questions will be entered into a hierarchical regression analysis to assess the unique proportion of variance of ‘wanting’ on excessive and problematic social media use. 

Hypothesis 3: Cue reactivity score to social media logos (i.e., cue reactivity rating for social media – control logos) will be analysed using a univariate linear regression. 

Hypothesis 4: First both automatic approach and avoidance tendencies for social media vs. control logos will be analysed using paired samples t-tests in order to investigate whether the sample as a whole had robust automatic approach or avoidance tendencies for social media. Next, the predictive value of the two variables will be assessed using a hierarchical linear regression. If the assumption of non-multicollinearity is not met, separate regression models will be used for approach vs avoidance RTs.

attributes.title: Post-Stroke Fatigue: A Scoping Review
attributes.description:
Background: Post-stroke fatigue (PSF) is one of the most common and frustrating outcomes of stroke. It has a high prevalence and it can persist for many years after stroke. PSF itself contributes to a wider range of undesirable outcomes that affect all aspects of daily life. The aim of this review was to identify and summarise the most recent research on PSF, in order to update the evidence base.
Methods: We updated an existing review (Hinkle et al. 2017) systematically searching CINAHL, MEDLINE, PsycINFO, and PubMed to cover new research studies between 1st March 2016 and the search date (19th January 2020). We included interventional and observational research, and clinical practice guidelines that were not covered in the original review. After duplicate removal in EndNote, two reviewers screened the search results in Rayyan, and data from eligible full texts were extracted onto an Excel spreadsheet. Finally, we used RobotReviewer and a human reviewer to assess the risk of bias of randomised trials for this scoping review.
Results: We identified 45 records for 30 studies (14 observational, 10 interventional studies, and 6 guidelines). Apart from one, the interventional studies were single-centred, had high risk of bias and small sample size (median 50). They investigated exercise, pharmacotherapy, psychotherapy, education, and light therapy. Observational studies mainly reported the factors related to PSF including co-morbidities, depression and anxiety, quality of life, activities of daily living, stroke severity, medication use and polypharmacy, polymorphism, pain, apathy, limb heaviness, neuroticism, mobility, and thyroid-stimulating hormone. Guidelines either did not report on PSF or, when reported, their recommendations were supported by little or low level of evidence.
Conclusion: Although we identified a number of recent studies which have added to our current knowledge on PSF, none are robust enough to change current clinical practice.

summary.value: This project contains the search strategies, risk of bias assessment document, PRISMA-ScR reporting checklist, and extracted data from the included studies.

registration_responses.summary: This project contains the search strategies, risk of bias assessment document, PRISMA-ScR reporting checklist, and extracted data from the included studies.

attributes.title: Does Cheating Have a Negative Affect on a Person's Self-perception
attributes.description: We aim to test the theory that cheating has a negative effect on a person's self perception. We individuals will show no negative effect of their self-perception when asked to lie or cheat under anxious/ stressful conditions.

q2.value: Individuals will show no negative effect of their self-perception when asked to lie or cheat under anxious/ stressful conditions.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (cheating or not cheating).

q7.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two equally sized, predetermined blocks.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: We have not used data that already exists for this study.

question.value: We plan on getting participants who work in businesses and/or college students. Participants will be recruited through advertisements on social media and business-based websites like Linkedin. Participants will be at least 18 years old and there will be consent forms where they agree to be willing to be placed in stressful conditions.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants; 100 for each study. We will attempt to recruit 250, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q12.value: (Will know more details after our hyp/sample review)

q13.value: We will post participant sign-up slots by week on the preceding Friday night, with 20 spots posted per week. We will post 20 new slots each week if, on that Friday night, we are below 320 participants.

question.value: The variables we plan to manipulate are the level of stress in the environment. We broke this down into 2 levels -- anxious and neutral
We will be measuring 2 variables. 1 -- ethics (if they would engage in unethical behavior ), and 2 -- the participants self-perception after partaking in an unethical behavior
We will not be creating a general combination for our variables.

We will be using a 2 X 2 ANOVA, all between- subjects. We will be comparing the anxious vs neutral stress environment with participants' likelihood to engage in unethical behaviors and their self-perception afterward.

q18.value: We do not plan on transforming, centering, recoding the data, or requiring a coding scheme for categorical variables.

q19.value: We will be using the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will also use a post hoc Tukey-Kramer test to adjust for multiple comparisons.

q20.value: We will verify that each subject answered all of the question criteria and ran through the experiment as a whole. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q21.value: If a participant does not complete our experiment or answer all of the questions they will be excluded in the analysis.

q22.value: We can explore demographics, age differences, and standard income when it comes to willingness to participate in unethical behaviors for a reward.

summary.value: The current registration includes a preregistration of analyses, R analysis scripts, and supplemental materials, all of which are openly available. The current registration also includes data which remain private due to personal information contained in the data.

attributes.title: The Distinct Effects of Empathic Accuracy for a Romantic Partner’s Appeasement and Dominance Negative Emotions
attributes.description: Data for the present study are posted on OSF but remain private since they include personal information. For more information about accessing the data, please contact Bonnie Le.

attributes.title: COVID Hypothesis Pre-Registration
attributes.description: Update of pre-registration for identity/social cure hypotheses (Packer) following some initial analysis of T1 data and prior to T2 data collection.  Analyses to date primarily examined factor structure of items related to key constructs and results of reported EFAs will guide our analytic strategy moving forward.

summary.value:
Update of pre-registration for identity/social cure hypotheses (Packer) following some initial analysis of T1 data and prior to T2 data collection.  Analyses to date primarily examined factor structure of items related to key constructs and results of reported EFAs will guide our analytic strategy moving forward. 

See specifics in file attached.

Analyses to date primarily examined factor structure of items related to key constructs and results of reported EFAs will guide our analytic strategy moving forward. 

See specifics in file attached.
